Text

CONVENTIONALLY [our]156-we life - story ended in a shower of rice at the church door , amid the scent of white flowers , with a flutter of white favors all about [us]156-we . [We]156-we left behind [us]156-we [those relatives whose presence had been so little desired by [us]156-we during [our]156-we brief courtship]157-those relatives whose presence had been so little desired by us during our brief courtship , and a high - heeled white satin slipper struck the back of the brougham as [we]156-we drove off . It was like a parting slap on the shoulder from [our]156-we old life — the old life which [we]156-we left so gayly , eager to fulfil the destiny set as the end of [our]156-we wooing 's fairy story , and to “ live happy ever after . ”[158-the fairy princess] And now all that was six months ago ; and instead of attending to that destiny , [the fairy princess]158-the fairy princess and [[her]158-the fairy princess unworthy prince]159-her unworthy prince were plunged over head and ears in [their]160-their first quarrel — [their]160-their first serious quarrel — about the real and earnest things of life ; for the other little quarrels about matters of sentiment and the affections really did not count . [They]160-their were only play and make - believe ; still , [they]160-their had got [our]156-we hands in , so that when [we]156-we really differed seriously [we]156-we both knew exactly how to behave — [we]156-we had played at quarrels so often . This quarrel was very serious , because it was about [my]0-i shaving - brush and [Chloe]45-chloe 's handkerchief - case . There was a cupboard with a window — [Chloe]45-chloe called it [[my]0-i dressing - room]161-my dressing - room , and , at first , [I]0-i humored [her]45-chloe pretty fancy about it , and pretended that [I]0-i could really see to shave in a glass that faced the window , although [my]0-i shoulders , as [I]0-i stood , cut off all light . But even then [I]0-i used really to shave at [Chloe]45-chloe 's mirror after [she]45-chloe had gone down to make the tea and boil the eggs — only [I]0-i kept [my]0-i shaving things in the embroidered vestments which [[my]0-i wife]162-my wife 's affection provided and [her]45-chloe fingers worked , and these lived in [the “ dressing - room]1608-the “ dressing - room . ”[45-chloe] But the subterfuge presently seemed unworthy , and [I]0-i found [myself]0-i , in the ardor of a truthful nature , leaving [my]0-i soapy brush on [her]45-chloe toilet - table . [Chloe]45-chloe called this untidiness , and worse , and urged that [I]0-i had [a dressing - room]163-a dressing - room . Then [I]0-i put the brush away . This had happened more than once . On this memorable morning [I]0-i had set up the pretty ivory shaving - brush , clean and pleasant with its white crown of lather , among [her]45-chloe hair - brushes . [Chloe]45-chloe came up just then to ask [me]0-i whether [I]0-i would have two or three eggs . [Her]45-chloe entrance startled [me]0-i . [I]0-i cut [myself]0-i slightly , but infuriatingly , and knocked the brush down . It fell on [Chloe]45-chloe 's handkerchief - case — pink satin , painted with rose and cupids , a present . [Chloe]45-chloe snatched it up . “ [You]0-i are horrid , ”[45-chloe] [she]45-chloe said . “ Why do n't [you]0-i shave in [[your]0-i own dressing - room]1609-your own dressing - room ? ”[45-chloe] “ Whatever does it matter ? ”[0-i] said [I.]0-i “ [My]45-chloe sachet 's ruined , ”[45-chloe] [she]45-chloe said , dabbing at it with [her]45-chloe pocket - handkerchief . [My]0-i chin was still bleeding . “ It 's no use , ”[45-chloe] [she]45-chloe went on . “ [I]45-chloe spend all [my]45-chloe time trying to keep [the house]1610-the house nice , and [you]0-i 're always putting things down on things . [You]0-i put [your]0-i hateful fountain - pen down on the new drawn - linen table - centre only yesterday , and it 's made a great ink mark . Yes , [you]0-i did — when [you]0-i were writing the check for [the butcher]1611-the butcher . ”[45-chloe] [I]0-i was ill - advised enough to murmur something about trifles . “ But they 're not trifles , ”[45-chloe] said [Chloe]45-chloe . “ They 're just the little things that make all the difference between [a home]1612-a home and — ”[45-chloe] “ And ? ”[45-chloe] “ And other places . Breakfast will be quite spoiled . [You]0-i 're frightfully late . And [I]45-chloe do n't think [this girl]1613-this girl means to stay ; [she]1613-this girl 's been quite rude about [the haddock]1614-the haddock already . ”[45-chloe] Now that [I]0-i knew what [[my]0-i wife]162-my wife was so cross about , [I]0-i might , perhaps — but [I]0-i did n't . [My]0-i chin was still bleeding . [I]0-i said , “ Please do n't wait breakfast for [me]0-i , and began to brush [my]0-i hair with a dignified aloofness . [Chloe]45-chloe went out , and [I]0-i own that [she]45-chloe banged the door . When [I]0-i was ready [I]0-i went down to breakfast . [Chloe]45-chloe was reading the paper — a thing [she]45-chloe never does . [She]45-chloe poured out [my]0-i tea and gave it to [me]0-i without a glance . Thanking [her]162-my wife coldly , [I]0-i helped [myself]0-i to haddock and opened [my]0-i letters . It was with the second letter that the shock came . [I]0-i read the letter twice . And [I]0-i looked round [[our]1615-our little dining - room]1616-our little dining - room — it was about ten feet by nine — and [I]0-i sighed . For [I]0-i knew — surely if inexplicably — that the dove of peace which had folded its wings there had spread them on a flight from which it would , perhaps , never return . [I]0-i had quarrelled with [[my]0-i wife]162-my wife — about a shaving - brush ; but that episode had now shrunk to less than nothing in the presence of the new , the wonderful danger that threatened [[our]1615-our home]1618-our home . [I]0-i looked at the neat breakfast - table , bright with [our]1615-our wedding - presents — cruet - stands , butter - dishes , and silver - plated teaspoons . [I]0-i looked at the row of shelves over the mantel - piece , where the more attractive of [our]1615-our crockery stood displayed ; at the corner cupboard , picked up for a song in [Great Portland Street]1-great portland street , and fitted with a lock inexorably guarding the marmalade , the loaf sugar , the sardines , the bottled beer , and such like costly items . [I]0-i looked at [Chloe]45-chloe , mutinously reading the paper — in a white muslin blouse which had been green , with white flowers on it , when [we]1615-our bought it together in [the Lewisham High Street]2-the lewisham high street for twopence three farthings [the yard]1619-the yard , and which to [my]0-i mind was all the prettier for the theft , by soap and water , of its original hue and design . [I]0-i looked at the remains of the haddock on the dish , the two eggs in the eggstand — another wedding - present . And again [I]0-i sighed . [Chloe]45-chloe laid down the paper irresolutely and looked towards , but not at , [me]0-i . [I]0-i sighed again and stirred [my]0-i tea . [I]0-i could see that [Chloe]45-chloe was making a heroic resolve to overcome [her]45-chloe pride and end the quarrel . [She]45-chloe did it . “[0-i] Are [you]165-you sorry [you]165-you were so cross ? ” [she]45-chloe asked , severely . “[165-you] Frightfully sorry . ” [I]165-you spoke from the heart . “[165-you] Then so am [I]0-i ! ” [she]45-chloe cried . And suddenly the first quarrel found itself over . Presently [we]1620-we went on with the breakfast . To be more accurate , [we]1620-we began . But [my]0-i thoughts refused to bury themselves in the beefsteak - pudding which [Chloe]45-chloe unfolded as a brilliant dinner prospect , and [I]0-i sighed once more . “[0-i] What is the matter now ? Have [you]165-you forgotten that [you]165-you 're not cross any more , and [you]165-you 're never going to be again — or — is the haddock really like [she]0-i said ? ” [Chloe]45-chloe asked , making horseshoes in [her]45-chloe pretty forehead , as [she]45-chloe always does when life presents to [her]45-chloe any problem not immediately soluble in a laugh or a joke . “[0-i] Is it another bill ? Never mind ! [I]0-i 'll ask [them]166-them to wait . [You]165-you 'll get the check for that detective story on Monday , if [the editor]167-the editor has a thread of conscience left , and [I]0-i 'll go up to [town]168-town to - morrow and draw the money from [old Moses]46-old moses for those last drawings of ‘ The Holy Life . ’ ” “[169-madam] It 's not a bill , [madam]169-madam , ” [I]46-old moses said , “[46-old moses] and [Moses]46-old moses can send [his]46-old moses money by post . To - morrow [we]170-we have another errand . To - day , alas ! [I]0-i must finish [my]0-i article for [the Weekly Wilderness]171-the weekly wilderness . ” “[0-i] Do [you]0-i want to drive [me]0-i to suicide ? ” [she]169-madam asked . “[0-i] Give [me]0-i the letter ! ” “[0-i] Allow [me]0-i , ” [I]0-i said , “[0-i] the melancholy pleasure of communicating its contents . If [you]169-madam have quite finished [your]169-madam eggs and things [you]169-madam may come and sit on [my]0-i knee . ” [She]169-madam came and perched [there]1621-there . “[169-madam] Do n't be a pig , [Len]47-len , ” [she]169-madam said . “[47-len] [I]0-i 'm not [a baby]172-a baby , to have bad news broken to [me]0-i . ” Then [I]0-i put [my]0-i arm round [her]169-madam and spoke out roundly . “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]173-my dear , ” [I]0-i said , “[0-i] [we]174-we are ruined . ” “[0-i] Oh , [Len]47-len , are [we]174-we really ? ” said [Chloe]45-chloe , much interested . “[47-len] Yes , ” [I]47-len said , firmly . “[47-len] Hitherto [we]174-we 've worked for [our]174-we living and earned it . Now [we]174-we are degraded from the ranks of [the noble army of [workers]176-workers]175-the noble army of workers . [[My]0-i uncle]177-my uncle [James]48-jim has died , and [he]48-jim has left [us]174-we a hundred a year and [a house]178-a house . [Our]174-we independence gone — it 's a cruel blow ! [We]174-we 'll ride over and see it to - morrow as ever is . ” [I]180-the girl am not sure that [Chloe]45-chloe did not weep for joy . Though as a rule , [one]1622-one knows , that sort of weeping is only done in books . [You]1623-you see , [we]174-we really had worked so very , very hard . However much in love one may be , [one]1622-one does not like to work ten hours a day . Though two may not grudge it as the price of life together . [I]180-the girl wrote , [Chloe]45-chloe illustrated — [we]174-we worked hard — hard — hard , and earned enough to keep body and soul and the two of [us]174-we together in [[our]174-we microscopic house]1625-our microscopic house . “[180-the girl] [The Bandbox]179-the bandbox ” [we]174-we called it , but on [its]179-the bandbox gatepost it called itself [Ross Villa]3-ross villa . And now — a hundred a year , and [a house]178-a house — such [a house]178-a house . It came back to [me]180-the girl out of [my]180-the girl youth , [a monument of comfortable affluence , with [vineries and pineries]1629-vineries and pineries , and pits and frames , clean - shaved lawns and [trim orchards]1630-trim orchards , [yew avenues]1631-yew avenues , box edgings , stabling and [coach - houses]1632-coach - houses and pigsties and henneries]1628-a monument of comfortable affluence , with vineries and pineries , and pits and frames , clean - shaved lawns and trim orchards , yew avenues , box edgings , stabling and coach - houses and pigsties and henneries . [Chloe]45-chloe and [I]180-the girl clung together in an ecstasy , till “[180-the girl] [the girl]180-the girl ” came in to clear away breakfast . [I]180-the girl never saw anything more dramatic than the way in which [she]45-chloe indicated , as [she]45-chloe bore out the empty dish , that [her]45-chloe opinion of the haddock was not only entirely unaltered , but indeed confirmed , by [our]174-we having eaten it . [My]180-the girl article for [the Weekly Wilderness]171-the weekly wilderness got itself written somehow , but with difficulty , for [Chloe]45-chloe , demoralized by [our]174-we good fortune , interrupted [me]180-the girl at every sentence — a thing [we]174-we have carefully trained each other not to do . “[180-the girl] Has it [a garden]181-a garden ? ” [she]45-chloe asked , suddenly , stopping in front of [me]180-the girl with a compelling wave of [her]45-chloe wand , or feather brush . “[180-the girl] Are [you]182-you sure it has [a garden]181-a garden ? ” “[182-you] More or less , ” [I]182-you said . “[182-you] Do n't chatter , there 's [an angel]184-an angel . ” “[184-an angel] And [out - houses]185-out - houses ? ” after a pause and an interval of fluffy energy . “[184-an angel] Of sorts , ” [I]184-an angel said ; “[184-an angel] but do n't talk , [[my]0-i dearest child]186-my dearest child . [You]186-my dearest child lost [me]0-i an epigram then . ” “[186-my dearest child] [I]0-i am so sorry — but — since [you]186-my dearest child are interrupted — dear , dearer , dearest [Len]47-len , tell [me]0-i in six words , what is [the Red House]187-the red house like ? ” “[47-len] [It]187-the red house 's not red at all — at least only one wing of [it]187-the red house . [It]187-the red house 's [a big yellow house]188-a big yellow house — stands all alone in [fields]189-fields . Has a great alarm - bell and , [I]0-i believe , a ghost . Now be quiet or [I]0-i shall slap [you]186-my dearest child . To - morrow [we]190-we 'll see it . ” But the interruption ruined a delightful sentence , conceived in a spirit of the most delicate irony , and dealing with the late deplorable action of [the London water companies]1634-the london water companies — and again [I]191-i experienced that premonition of unrest . Never again , [I]191-i felt certain , should [I]191-i be able to be sure of a clear morning 's work . [I]191-i made allowances for [[my]191-i wife]162-my wife . [I]191-i was not , [I]191-i feel certain , unjust or unreasonable , but [I]191-i saw that while [the house]1610-the house and the money were new topics , [she]162-my wife could not be expected to preserve on them the hours of silence which [my]191-i writing exacted . And by the time the topics were stale , the beautiful habit of letting each other alone during working - hours would have been broken forever . [I]191-i laid down [my]191-i fountain - pen to make these reflections . [I]191-i heard [Chloe]45-chloe pulling out drawers and opening cupboards in [[our]1637-our room]1638-our room overhead . Yet before [I]191-i could snatch up [my]191-i pen [she]45-chloe had whirled in and caught [me]191-i idle . “[191-i] Oh , [you]191-i 're not doing anything . Then [I]0-i sha'n't interrupt [you]191-i if [I]0-i just ask whether there 's [a hen - house]192-a hen - house . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know , ” [I]0-i said , beginning to write very fast , and not sufficiently grateful , [I]0-i fear , for [her]45-chloe indifference to the money as compared with [the house]1610-the house . “[0-i] Why do n't [you]191-i settle down to [your]191-i work ? This is the beginning of the ruin [I]0-i foresaw . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i — [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i 'll work to - day , ” [she]45-chloe said , guiltily . “[0-i] [I]0-i 'm looking over some things . But [I]0-i wo n't bother . ” But [she]45-chloe was back again in less than half an hour with a question about larders burning on [her]45-chloe lips , and [my]0-i article degenerated from the clear , sustained logical argument which it meant to be , to a piece of patch - work — of patch - work ill fitted . [I]0-i became desperate , and avenged [my]0-i poor broken article by telling [Chloe]45-chloe anything rather than the truth about [[[my]0-i uncle]177-my uncle 's old house]1641-my uncle 's old house . In the end this disingenuousness was paid for to the uttermost . If [I]0-i had prepared [her]45-chloe , if [I]0-i had had the intelligence to overpaint , even , the charms of [that old house]1642-that old house — but [I]0-i was firm , firm to the point of spitefulness . “[0-i] [A yellow brick house]193-a yellow brick house , as ugly as [a lunatic asylum]194-a lunatic asylum , standing alone in [the fields]195-the fields , bearing an alarm - bell and a ghostly reputation . ” This was the most [she]45-chloe got out of [me]0-i . [My]0-i piece of patch - work got its last stitches put in sooner than [I]0-i expected . [I]0-i put it in its envelope , addressed it , and went up to [[our]1643-our room]1638-our room . All the wardrobe drawers were pulled out . [Chloe]45-chloe was sitting on the floor amid a heap of stuffs — a roll of chintz which [[her]45-chloe mother]1645-her mother had given [her]45-chloe for covers to [our]1643-our drawing - room furniture , if ever [we]1643-our had any ; some bits of velvet , soft reds and greens , that [we]1643-our had bought together at [Liberty]49-liberty 's sale ; and [she]45-chloe was snipping and tearing at a muslin and lace gown — a gown [I]0-i had always admired . [I]0-i remember [she]45-chloe wore it to breakfast the day after [our]1643-our wedding . [I]0-i felt as though [my]0-i tenderest memories were being unpicked , stitch by stitch . “[0-i] What on earth — ” [I]0-i said . [She]45-chloe looked up with a flush of excitement on [her]45-chloe little face . “[0-i] Oh , [Len]47-len , look here . Do n't [you]47-len think these velvets would cover some cushions very nicely ? And the chintz would make lovely long curtains , and [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could get at least four short blinds out of this muslin for [the new house]196-the new house . ” [My]0-i blood actually ran cold . [I]0-i sat down suddenly on the clothes - basket . [Chloe]45-chloe was not too preoccupied to tell [me]0-i not to , for perhaps the twentieth time . “[0-i] [You]47-len know it wo n't bear [your]47-len weight , ” [she]45-chloe said . “[0-i] Look here . [I]0-i shall put the lace like that , and like that , and tie it back with yellow ribbon . [I]0-i 've got a soft sash here . ” [She]45-chloe got up , scattering muslin and velvet , and began to turn over a corner drawer . [I]0-i found a trembling tongue . “[0-i] But , [[my]0-i dear child]197-my dear child , [we]198-we ca n't live in [the house]1610-the house . ” [She]45-chloe dropped a lace scarf and [her]45-chloe best ivory prayer - book to look at [me]198-we . “[198-we] But why ? ” “[198-we] It 's too big . [We]198-we ca n't afford it . ” “[198-we] But [we]198-we pay rent for this — and [we]198-we should n't for that . ” “[198-we] It 's impossible . Why , of course [we]198-we must let it . It ought to bring [us]198-we in a couple of hundred a year . ” [Chloe]45-chloe 's eyes actually filled with tears . “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]173-my dear , [[my]0-i dear]173-my dear , ” [I]0-i said , “[0-i] this is very terrible . Is it possible that after so short a time [I]0-i find [you]173-my dear longing to leave the Bandbox — [[our]198-we own little Bandbox]202-our own little bandbox — the pride and joy of [our]198-we hearts ? ” [She]45-chloe came to [me]0-i then and asked [me]0-i not to be so horrid . “[0-i] Do n't tease , ” [she]45-chloe said , “[0-i] just when [I]0-i was so pleased , too ! [You]0-i do n't know how [I]0-i hate [the people next door]203-the people next door , [Len]47-len . Oh , fancy having [no one next door]204-no one next door ! [I]0-i 'd live in [a barn]205-a barn on those terms . ” [I]0-i talked to [her]45-chloe in a thoroughly reasonable way , and [she]45-chloe presently promised that [she]45-chloe also would be reasonable . [She]45-chloe agreed that [we]198-we must let [the house]1610-the house . Also [she]45-chloe insisted that as [I]0-i had finished [my]0-i work , [we]198-we should go at once and look at it . [I]0-i in [my]0-i turn agreed . It was while [I]0-i was lacing [my]0-i boots that [she]45-chloe said , sighing : “[0-i] Well , it is hard . But [you]47-len say it 's absolutely hideous — that 's one comfort . ” Even then [I]47-len might have put up an arm to ward off the blow fate was aiming at [me]47-len , but [my]47-len bootlace was in a hard knot , and [I]47-len said nothing on any other subject . In the hour when afternoon ends and evening begins , [we]198-we set out to see [the Red House]187-the red house . [We]198-we rode [our]198-we bicycles , of course . Poor as [we]198-we were , [we]198-we could yet command , on the hire system , machines which , at any rate , in [their]1648-their first youth , might have been the desire of [princes]1649-princes . Once [we]198-we had passed [the dusty avenue of little villas]1650-the dusty avenue of little villas ( wherein [our]198-we Bandbox , [the corner house]1651-the corner house , squeezed in between [two more portly brethren]1652-two more portly brethren , is of all the most unworthy ) , and had done the three miles of respectable semi - detachedness which form on this side of [town]168-town [the outer fringe of [London]4-london 's loathly suburbs]1654-the outer fringe of london 's loathly suburbs , [our]198-we way lay through green lanes where hawthorns were budding in pink and pearl . And here [I]47-len received a final note of warning . “[47-len] Oh , [Len]47-len , ” [Chloe]45-chloe sighed , reining in [her]45-chloe shining steed to gaze wistfully on the trim green of [the scattered suburban pleasaunces]1655-the scattered suburban pleasaunces , “[47-len] if [we]206-we could only live out here — away from the washing and [the organ - grinders]207-the organ - grinders and [the people next door]203-the people next door ! Oh — [I]0-i know [we]206-we can't — but [I]0-i wish [we]206-we could . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish so , too , ” [I]0-i said , briskly . It was merely a polite acquiescence in [her]45-chloe aspiration , but it was noted . [I]0-i , [blind mole]1656-blind mole , noted nothing . The most explicit warnings pass [us]198-we by unheeded ; it is only after the doom stroke has fallen that [we]198-we perceive the significance of portents . [We]198-we climbed [the hill]1657-the hill and passed through [the long , sunny village street]1658-the long , sunny village street , clamorous now with bean - feasters and superior private pleasure parties in wagonettes drawn up in front of [the “[0-i] Spotted Dog ” and “[0-i] The Chequers ”]1659-the “ spotted dog ” and “ the chequers ” and [the “[0-i] Castle Hotel]1660-the “ castle hotel , ” for was it not Saturday , and [the village]1661-the village but a bare ten miles from [Charing Cross]5-charing cross ? Then came the sharp turn to the left , the delicious downward rush through hawthorn - scented air , the black bar of shadow from [the railway bridge]1662-the railway bridge , [a red cottage]1663-a red cottage , a red wall , tall chestnut - trees , pyramids of green fan - leaves and miraculous - scented flowers — a green gate . “[0-i] This is it , ” [I]0-i said , and [Chloe]45-chloe brought down the brake in that reckless way of [hers]45-chloe , and sprang to the ground . The sun - blistered , old , green gate swung long and wide on loud , red , rusty hinges as [we]198-we led [our]198-we beasts in . [We]198-we left [them]1664-them under the biggest of the chestnut - trees , and walked up [the wide , moss - grown drive]1665-the wide , moss - grown drive to where the front door , fortified by heavy stone pillars , seemed to defy [us]198-we , [the besiegers]1666-the besiegers . “[0-i] Is this really it ? ” asked [Chloe]45-chloe , in a whisper . And well might [she]45-chloe ask . The yellow brick on which in [my]0-i talk [I]0-i had laid so much stress was hidden almost — at any rate transformed , transfigured — by a net - work of great leaves and red buds ; creepers covered it — all but . And at the side there were jasmine that in July nights would be starry and scented , and wistaria , purple - flowered and yellow - leaved over its thick , gnarled boughs , and ivy ; and at the back , where [the shaky green veranda]1667-the shaky green veranda is overhung by the perilous charm of [the white balcony]1668-the white balcony , Virginia - creepers and climbing roses grew in a thorny maze . [The moat]1669-the moat was there , girdling the old lawns — where once [the Elizabethan manor]1670-the elizabethan manor stood — with a belt of silver , a sad swan and [a leaky boat]1671-a leaky boat keeping [each other]1672-each other company . Yellow laburnums trailed [their]1673-their long hair in the water , and sweet lilac - bushes swayed to look at their pretty plumes reflected in it . To right and left stretched the green tangled mysteries of [the overgrown gardens]1674-the overgrown gardens . [We]198-we stepped back onto the bridge that crosses [the moat]1669-the moat , and looked up at [the tall house]1676-the tall house . Before the ivy dressed [it]1676-the tall house , [it]1676-the tall house must have been very ugly . [I]0-i suspect [[my]0-i uncle]177-my uncle of having had that ivy clipped to its last leaf every spring ; and [he]177-my uncle must have had [the house]1610-the house scraped and “[0-i] pointed ” pretty often . How otherwise account for the yellow brick hideousness that glared at [me]209-you through the mist of the years lying between [me]209-you and [my]209-you childhood ? [The Red House]187-the red house is square , and very tall , but [it]187-the red house has two large , low , long wings ending in [four square brick turrets with pointed roofs]1680-four square brick turrets with pointed roofs . But ca n't [we]210-we get in ? ” [We]198-we could n't , because [I]209-you had forgotten to call at [[the plumber]1681-the plumber 's in [the village]1661-the village]1682-the plumber 's in the village for the key . “[209-you] But [I]0-i 'll go back for it , ” [I]0-i said , “[0-i] only — [I]0-i did n't think of it — [the shop]211-the shop 's sure to be shut . It 's Saturday , [you]209-you know . ” “[209-you] Then [we]210-we wo n't waste time , ” said [Chloe]45-chloe , firmly . “[210-we] Let 's be [burglars]212-burglars . Break a pane of glass , and let 's get in by a window . ” Already [she]45-chloe was stooping for a stone . “[209-you] Well — if [you]209-you insist . But let 's at least find a window without shutters . ” [We]210-we went round [the house]1610-the house and round [the house]1610-the house , like the snow in the riddle ; but every window had its eyelids down , as [Chloe]45-chloe said . “[210-we] Stupid , sleepy thing , ” [she]45-chloe said , “[210-we] [we]210-we must wake it up . Ca n't [you]209-you climb up to [the balcony]213-the balcony and get in [there]1621-there ? ” “[209-you] Shutters again , ” [I]209-you said . “[209-you] [[My]0-i worthy uncle]215-my worthy uncle believed in them . But — ” [I]215-my worthy uncle was looking at the thick , twisted stems of the ivy that clung to the wall of the low left wing . “[215-my worthy uncle] There used to be an apple - room with a window opening on the leads . In happier days — ” “[218-you'll] Happier ? ” “[218-you'll] No — earlier ! [I]0-i have climbed up the ivy in [my]0-i time . But [I]0-i dare say [the apple - room]216-the apple - room is locked . And [I]0-i went up the ivy . It was as easy as going up a ladder ; but [I]0-i own that as [I]0-i stepped onto the leads [I]0-i did not expect to hear [[my]0-i wife]162-my wife 's voice just below [my]0-i feet , saying , “[0-i] Look out — [you'll]218-you'll kick [me]0-i . ” [She]162-my wife had climbed up the ivy behind [me]219-i . [The old garden]1701-the old garden had always been beautiful to [me]0-i , even in the days when [I]0-i used secretly to eat gooseberries there , and plums , and peaches in an unripe state ; and [it]1701-the old garden was beautiful now , even as [I]0-i remembered it , only now [its]1701-the old garden trees and bushes were incredibly grown — moss- cushioned its paths . [City gentleman]1712-city gentleman after [city gentleman]1712-city gentleman approached and retreated after a parley , that always ended in suggestions for repairs to the tune of from four to five hundred pounds . At first [each new applicant]1714-each new applicant was to [me]0-i an object of interest , and to [Chloe]45-chloe an object of jealous detestation . But [Chloe]45-chloe laughed , a laugh of triumph and delight . [We]264-we used to ride over there every day to see if [the house]1610-the house was let , and it never was ; and more and more flowers came out in [the garden]223-the garden — old , small sweet tulips and forget - [me]0-i - nots and hearts - ease , and the roses were in tiny bud . And never for a day did [Chloe]45-chloe cease to cry for the moon . The 27th of May is [her]45-chloe birthday . It is also the anniversary of the day on which [I]0-i first met [her]45-chloe . And [I]281-you — well , as [you]281-you see , if [Chloe]45-chloe only “[281-you] keeps all on , ” [I]281-you am foolish enough for anything . “[281-you] [YOU]281-you look like a historical picture , ” [Chloe]45-chloe said . “[281-you] What's - [his]285-his - name weeping over the ruins of Somewhere or other . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am weeping , over the ruins of [[my]0-i happy home]286-my happy home , ” [I]0-i replied , as [I]0-i sat on a packing - case and stirred with [my]0-i boot - toe a tangle of brown paper , string , dust , and empty bottles on the dining - room floor . “[0-i] Nonsense ! ” [she]45-chloe said . “[281-you] [[Your]281-you happy home]287-your happy home 's where [I]0-i am , is n't it ? ” “[281-you] That 's just what [I]0-i say . [This adorable Bandbox of ours]288-this adorable bandbox of ours contained [my]0-i heart 's one treasure , and therefore — ” “[0-i] If [you]281-you mean [me]0-i , ” [she]45-chloe said , briskly , “[0-i] [your]281-you treasure is not going to be kept in [a Bandbox]289-a bandbox any longer . [It]290-it is going to live in [a palace]291-a palace — ” “[290-it] Unfurnished — replete with — ” “[290-it] Historic associations and other delights , ” [she]45-chloe interrupted . “[290-it] And not quite unfurnished , either . [Poor , dear boy]292-poor , dear boy — was it unhappy at the nasty flitting , then ? And was [it]293-it like a cat , and did [it]293-it hate to leave [[its]293-it own house]294-its own house ? [It]293-it shall have [its]293-it paws buttered — its boots , [I]0-i mean — the minute [we]295-our get into [the new house]196-the new house ! ” [She]45-chloe came and sat beside [me]293-it on the packing - case , and [I]293-it absently put [my]293-it arm round [her]45-chloe . “[293-it] Allow [me]0-i a moment for natural regrets , ” [I]293-it said . “[293-it] It is not fair to distract [my]0-i mind with undue influence when [I]0-i 'm watching the dark waters of time close over the wreck of [that good ship]297-that good ship , the Bandbox . ” “[293-it] That 's fine writing , ” [she]45-chloe said , contemptuously . “[293-it] Talk sensibly , there 's [a good boy]298-a good boy . ” Acquiescing , [I]298-a good boy pinched [her]45-chloe ears softly . What [[my]298-a good boy wife]162-my wife terms sensible conversation is unworthy to be reported . [The Bandbox]179-the bandbox lay before [us]295-our , so to speak , in little bits . All the curtains were down , and all the pictures . [The crockery]1727-the crockery was packed up , so were the wedding - presents . The saucepans and kettles sat in a forlorn group on [the sitting - room floor]1728-the sitting - room floor . [Our]295-our comfortable beds were now nothing but rolls of striped ticking and long , iron bands — lying about where one could best trip over them . The wall - papers , which had looked so bright and pleasant with [our]295-our books and pictures on them , now showed , in patches of aggressively unfaded color , the outlines of the shelves and frames that had hung against them . The fire that had boiled [our]295-our breakfast - kettle had gone out , and the cold ashes looked inexpressibly desolate . As [we]295-our sat awaiting the arrival of [our]295-our green - grocer , who had undertaken to “[298-a good boy] move ” [us]295-our , [I]0-i pointed out the ashes to [Chloe]45-chloe . “[0-i] [I]0-i believe [you]298-a good boy would like to put some on [your]298-a good boy head , ” said [she]0-i . [The green - grocer]1729-the green - grocer had promised to come at nine o'clock . That was why [we]295-our had got up in the middle of the night , and finished [our]295-our packing before eight o'clock . It was now past ten . “[298-a good boy] [He]299-he has thought better of it , ” said [I.]0-i “[299-he] [He]299-he is [a far - seeing man]300-a far - seeing man , and a kindly . [He]299-he knows it can not be for [our]301-our real good to leave [our]301-our Bandbox . Let 's set to work and put all the things back in [their]302-their places ! ” “[299-he] Here [he]299-he is , ” said [Chloe]45-chloe , jumping off the packing - case at the squeaking sound which ever preludes any weak effort on the part of the Bandbox door - knocker . “[299-he] Oh , [Len]47-len , ” [she]45-chloe whispered , in awestruck tones , “[47-len] it is n't [the men]303-the men ! [I]0-i can see through the door - glass , and it 's [a lady]304-a lady , and look at [me]0-i ! ” “[304-a lady] Life hardly offers a dearer pleasure ! ” said [I]304-a lady , and indeed , in [her]45-chloe white gown and blue pinafore , with [her]45-chloe brown hair loose and ruffled , [she]45-chloe made so pretty a picture that [I]304-a lady could not help thinking how [a really high - toned green - grocer]1730-a really high - toned green - grocer might well have refused base coin as the price of “[304-a lady] moving ” [us]301-our , counting [himself]1730-a really high - toned green - grocer well paid by the sight of [her]45-chloe . “[304-a lady] [I]0-i 'll go , if [you]305-you like , ” [I]45-chloe said , and went . [Chloe]45-chloe hid [herself]45-chloe behind the [kitchen]1731-kitchen door , where the jack - towel used to hang . Even its roller had been unscrewed and packed now . “[45-chloe] [Chloe]45-chloe ! ” [I]45-chloe called , “[45-chloe] it 's all right . [At]306-at least [I]0-i was last week , and shall be again next . [I]0-i 've just run over for a few days on business , and [I]0-i slipped away to [the Bandbox]179-the bandbox to rest [my]0-i eyes with a look at the turtle - doves . But they do n't look restful at all . ” [She]0-i was taking the long , pearl - headed pins out of [her]0-i hat as [she]0-i spoke . “[52-yolande] Oh ! ” said [[my]52-yolande wife]162-my wife , again . “[52-yolande] Sit down — no — not on that — it 's crocks and newspapers — and the chairs are all packed . [We]309-we 're moving into [a house with [twenty - nine rooms]311-twenty - nine rooms in [it]310-a house with twenty - nine rooms in it]310-a house with twenty - nine rooms in it . ” Then the whole story came out — of [Chloe]45-chloe 's folly and of [my]52-yolande madness . [His]57-charley clothes and those of [[his]57-charley friends]1745-his friends smelled strange and stuffy , as though they had been smeared with putty and mutton fat , and locked away for years in a cupboard full of pickled onions and yellow soap and mice . The clothes of [the unskilled laborer]1746-the unskilled laborer always have this strange scent . It lingers about everything [they]1746-the unskilled laborer touch in passing through [a house]178-a house , and after days its freshness is still unimpaired . It was rather a nice set , too , dark green , that [Yolande]52-yolande had brought from [Italy]8-italy , and , by [us]344-we , here , totally irreplaceable . [Its]1772-our bandbox bare windows blinked forlornly at [us]357-we in the June sunlight like the eyes of [a deserted orphan]1774-a deserted orphan . [We]357-we rode on in silence . [We]357-we passed [our]357-we furniture about half a mile from [the Bandbox]179-the bandbox . And [we]357-we had been keeping [our]357-we tempers for more than two hours in [the spacious emptiness of [the Red House]187-the red house]1776-the spacious emptiness of the red house before the rattle of harness and the scent of [Charley]57-charley 's coat announced the arrival of [the van]1763-the van . [Charley]57-charley and [[his]57-charley minions]1779-his minions made a hollow pretence of putting the furniture in its place . [They]357-we did put the bedsteads together , insecurely , and in [the wrong rooms]1780-the wrong rooms ; and [they]357-we set up “[359-the next people who live in you] chesties of drawerses ” against walls . The oak chests [they]357-we carried to [the attic]1781-the attic , and the best steel fire - irons were discovered , weeks later , in [the cellar]1782-the cellar . But almost everything — saucepans , crockery , coal - scuttles , books , hearth - rugs , stair - rods , fenders — was dumped on the floors of [the hall]1783-the hall , [the kitchen]236-the kitchen , and [the dining - room]1785-the dining - room . [I]359-the next people who live in you remember that [I]359-the next people who live in you had to move half a ton of mixed valuables to find the tea - kettle , when , after two hours of breathless energy , [we]1786-we heard [the van]1763-the van 's retreating wheels , and were moved towards [the kitchen]236-the kitchen by one common longing — for tea . [Chloe]45-chloe got the tea , and [I]359-the next people who live in you cleared it away . [Harriet]55-harriet reluctantly consented to wash up the tea - things . “[359-the next people who live in you] But , ” [she]0-i added , and it really was like a blow in the wind , “[359-the next people who live in you] [I]0-i must get away before dark . No , it ai n't no manner of use talking . There 's [ghosts]361-ghosts in this ' ouse , and [I]0-i would n't sleep under this ' ere roof , not for any wages [you]362-you could offer . ” In vain [we]1786-we besought [her]0-i to reconsider this decision . “[58-mother] [Mother]58-mother always said to [me]0-i , ‘ Do n't [you]362-you never lay [your]362-you ' ead on [your]362-you pillow in a ' ouse where there 's ghosts , or [you]362-you 'll see ['em]363-'em walk — safe as eggs . [We]419-we took down the wet curtains and hung them on the bacon - rack in [the kitchen]236-the kitchen . “[0-i] [I]0-i do wish [we]419-we kept a pig , ” said [Chloe]45-chloe , in parenthesis . “[0-i] Fancy sides of bacon swinging here , instead of wet , floppy , droppy curtains ! ” It was a night 's work . When the gray of the dawn showed [us]419-we , through rain - wrinkled window - panes , the green tangle of [[our]419-we garden]1847-our garden , all beaten down to one dripping desolation , with a gray sky above , and over all the rain , [I]0-i looked at [[my]0-i wife]162-my wife and said : “[0-i] This has been an adventurous night . It is a ghastly morning . Do [people who have been up all night]420-people who have been up all night have breakfast ? Tea , for instance ? [You]421-you are wet as [any mermaid]422-any mermaid , and twice as pretty . But water 's not [your]421-you native element . [You]421-you must be dried . [I]0-i 'll light a fire . ” [She]162-my wife had caught at the rope of bright hair that hung below [her]162-my wife waist , and was wringing the water out of it . [Her]162-my wife bare feet were pink and rosy in the mixed radiance of dawn and candlelight . [Her]162-my wife striped red - and - white skirts gave [her]162-my wife a sort of coquettish smartness , as of a Parisienne at [Trouville]13-trouville . [She]162-my wife held out [her]162-my wife hand with a dramatic gesture . “[0-i] Come with [[your]421-you mermaid]423-your mermaid , ” [she]162-my wife said ; “[0-i] come and light a fire of driftwood in [[her]423-your mermaid ocean cave]424-her ocean cave . ” [She]162-my wife led [me]0-i through [the kitchen]236-the kitchen to [the little room where [we]1851-we worked]1850-the little room where we worked . A fire burned red and glowing ; on [her]162-my wife drawing - table , white damask covered , were bread , butter , tea - things . The brass kettle sang softly on the hob . “[0-i] The ghost must have done this , ” said [I.]0-i “[423-your mermaid] [You]423-your mermaid said [you]423-your mermaid 'd make it run errands , but [I]0-i never thought [you]423-your mermaid 'd get it to light fires . ” “[423-your mermaid] But [I]0-i did , [you]421-you see , ” said [Chloe]45-chloe . “[0-i] [I]0-i taught it — little odd minutes when [you]421-you were carrying buckets and sticking up damp books on [their]425-their poor tails , so that [you]421-you should n't notice what [I]0-i was doing . Is n't it [a clever ghost]426-a clever ghost ? Are n't [I]0-i [a good teacher]427-a good teacher ? ” “[423-your mermaid] [You]423-your mermaid are [an angel]184-an angel , ” [I]184-an angel said . “[184-an angel] [I]0-i 'll make the tea . ” “[0-i] Are n't [I]0-i [a noble wife]429-a noble wife ? Are n't [you]421-you proud of [me]0-i ? Do n't [you]421-you love [me]0-i very , very , very ? ” said [she]0-i . “[421-you] Not exactly , ” said [I]421-you , holding [her]0-i in one arm and making the tea with the other . “[421-you] Respect , admiration for [your]423-your mermaid talents — look out , [you]423-your mermaid nearly had the teapot over!—but love ! Do n't be exacting — and do n't shake [my]0-i arm , or [I]0-i shall scald [us]430-us both . Go ! Run ! [Skurry]61-skurry ! ” “[61-skurry] The potted meat is in the chiffonnier , ” [she]0-i said . “[61-skurry] Are [you]421-you going to keep wet ? ” “[421-you] Yes , [I]0-i 've got to go out and see what there is on the roof , as soon as it 's light enough to see to put up a ladder . [Madam]169-madam , withdraw , and take five drops of eucalyptus oil on a piece of sugar . ” It was rather a pleasant breakfast , though the drip , drip , drip went on merrily all the time . When the last sandwich had vanished [Chloe]45-chloe put [her]45-chloe elbows on the table and said : “[47-len] [Len]47-len , [I]0-i 'm afraid it 's very wrong , but [I]0-i 've rather enjoyed [myself]0-i . [I]0-i seem to like things to happen . But , oh , what a mess everything is in ! ” “[0-i] It is , ” said [I]0-i , “[0-i] but [I]0-i do , too . And it is wicked — a morbid craving for excitement , even at the expense of [a cherished library]432-a cherished library — the cream of [our]433-we country 's literature . Now put on [your]423-your mermaid macker , and [we]433-we 'll go up on the roof . ” [I]45-chloe helped [her]45-chloe into [her]45-chloe mackintosh , and [we]433-we went . The roof of [the white parlor]257-the white parlor is one of [the leaded spaces on the wings of [the Red House]187-the red house]1853-the leaded spaces on the wings of the red house . [It]1855-it has a parapet at back and front . These formed a sort of tank ; all the waste - pipes were stuffed up with leaves and twigs , and [I]45-chloe pulled a black , sodden starlings ' nest out of one of them . The rain came down pitilessly . [I]45-chloe looked about [me]45-chloe . [I]45-chloe knew that , below , the flood in [the white parlor]257-the white parlor must be momently gaining in depth and intensity . “[45-chloe] [Chloe]45-chloe , ” [I]45-chloe said , “[45-chloe] this is no time to be tender of bricks and mortar . Go and fetch the bass - broom , and [I]0-i will seek for the coal - hammer . ” [I]0-i found it , after some search , in [the pantry]1692-the pantry . [I]0-i had taken it [there]1621-there [myself]0-i , [I]0-i remember , in the avowed belief that it , and it only , could serve to break into the first gooseberry pie of [Chloe]45-chloe 's making . [I]0-i brought [it]1855-it up onto the roof , and with it smashed away the bricks and cement till [I]0-i had a two - foot embrasure in the back parapet . Then [I]0-i paused . A moment 's silence full of concentrated reflection broke as [I]0-i said , “[0-i] Wife of [my]0-i heart , to think that quite by accident [you]45-chloe have married [a mechanical genius]434-a mechanical genius ! ” Then [we]1859-we went to find the spade . With it [we]1859-we dug clay from the banks of one of [the little streams which feed [our]1859-we moat]1860-the little streams which feed our moat . [I]435-beloved transported [it]1855-it in the wheelbarrow , always through the rain , to the scene of action , and [we]1859-we raised it to the roof by a cord and the waste - paper basket . With it [I]435-beloved built a dam round [[my]435-beloved embrasure]1861-my embrasure . Then again [I]435-beloved paused in Napoleonic meditation , and then — “[435-beloved] The dust - pan , [beloved]435-beloved , ” [I]435-beloved said , looking down on [[my]435-beloved wife]162-my wife 's pink , rain - wet face . Then [I]435-beloved knocked over the last three inches at the bottom of [[my]435-beloved embrasure]1861-my embrasure . The water from within [[my]435-beloved dam]1864-my dam rushed out down the face of [the house]1610-the house — behind the dam lay the tank of water , but [my]435-beloved dam held firm . “[435-beloved] And now a broom - handle , soul of [my]0-i soul — or , [I]0-i 'll tell [you]435-beloved what , that garden rake [we]436-we 've never used , and some clothes - line . ” [I]45-chloe spliced the dust - pan 's handle at right angles gles to the handle of the rake , and laid this last across the embrasure . The parapet held its ends securely , and the dust - pan , face downward , projected itself out through the opening . [I]45-chloe made all fast with clay and then called [Chloe]45-chloe to come up the step - ladder and share with [me]45-chloe the triumphant moment when [my]45-chloe dam should be broken down and [my]45-chloe new dust - pan - cum - rake water - shoot come into play . [[One]1622-one 's wife]1867-one 's wife should share [one]1622-one 's joys as well as [one]1622-one 's sorrows , [I]45-chloe said . The ingenious contrivance , which [I]45-chloe thrilled to have found [myself]45-chloe capable of devising , acted perfectly . [I]45-chloe kicked [my]45-chloe dam to pieces , and the imprisoned water behind rushed impetuously through the embrasure , and , directed by [the trusty dust - pan]1870-the trusty dust - pan , fell in a cataract a yard and a half from [the house]1610-the house , to meander away harmlessly along [the gravel path]1872-the gravel path . [I]45-chloe helped the flowing tide with the bass - broom , and all the while the rain splashed and spun and sputtered on mackintosh and bared heads . When the leads held but half an inch of water [I]45-chloe strengthened the dust - pan and rake with clay , and [we]1873-we went [indoors]1874-indoors . [The white parlor]257-the white parlor was unspeakably wet — but the water no longer dripped from the roof . [We]1873-we mopped again , dried and dressed , and did [our]1873-we ordinary house - work . Then the sun came out . [We]1873-we took cushions and rugs onto [the balcony]213-the balcony , and fell asleep . [We]1873-we slept till late in the afternoon . Then [I]45-chloe went to fetch [a plumber]1877-a plumber . [He]1877-a plumber came , many days later , cleared the wastepipes , and sent [me]45-chloe in a bill for £ 2 17s . 7d . This was the first charge on the legacy [we]1873-we had received from [[my]45-chloe uncle]177-my uncle . The second was made by [the inspector of [the water company]1880-the water company]1879-the inspector of the water company . [He]1879-the inspector of the water company compelled [us]1873-we to put in new patent taps all over [the house]1610-the house . This cost £ 7 9s . 3d . ; and when a grand - maternal government came down on [us]1873-we about the question of sinks and overflow - pipes — [Chloe]45-chloe , in [my]45-chloe absence , had the misfortune to cringe before its minion — the matter ended in a bill of £ 29 19s . 11d . Then [I]45-chloe said : “[45-chloe] [Chloe]45-chloe , ruin stares [us]437-we in the face . When [we]437-we lived in [the Bandbox]179-the bandbox — ” “[45-chloe] Yes , [I]0-i know , ” [she]0-i interrupted , “[45-chloe] but there 's such a lot to do [here]231-here . ” “[45-chloe] The ' ouse is too large and the work too ' eavy , ” [I]45-chloe quoted . “[45-chloe] It is n't that , but everything 's so large , ” [she]0-i said . “[0-i] Why , it takes [me]0-i two hours to do the flowers , and they must be done three times a week at least . ” “[437-we] [We]437-we must go flowerless , [Chloe]45-chloe , or seek [the refuge of [the neighboring workhouse]441-the neighboring workhouse]440-the refuge of the neighboring workhouse . Now , in [the Bandbox]6-the bandbox — ” “[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i know , ” [she]0-i said again . “[0-i] Oh , [Len]47-len , do n't scold — it 's horrid of [you]47-len ! ” Remorselessly [I]47-len pursued [my]47-len advantage , for [Chloe]45-chloe seemed to be in a yielding mood . “[47-len] In [the Bandbox]6-the bandbox — ” [I]47-len began , but [she]0-i caught [me]47-len by the shoulders and shook [me]47-len and took the words out of [my]47-len mouth . “[47-len] In [the Bandbox]179-the bandbox , ” [she]0-i said , “[0-i] [I]0-i worked and [you]47-len worked . And now [we]443-we do n't [either of [us]443-we]1721-either of us work a bit more than [we]443-we can help . And [I]0-i know why it is , too — [we've]443-we both found out how interesting other things are . [You]47-len 'd rather chop wood or clean the boots than write [your]47-len nasty , dull articles and stories , and [I]0-i 'd rather put up shelves and arrange flowers than draw silly pictures of [idiotic people]445-idiotic people for imbecile magazines . [We]443-we 're both demoralized by — what do [you]47-len call it?—the joy of life . [I]0-i hate work . It was not in the dresser drawer , after all , but on the bottom shelf of the oak side - board , and [I]45-chloe had to iron it before [I]45-chloe could dream of putting it on . [Chloe]45-chloe told [me]45-chloe how to do it , but [she]45-chloe owned that [I]45-chloe did it far better than [she]45-chloe could have done it [herself]45-chloe . [My]45-chloe best boots were mislaid , too , as it happened , and , before [I]45-chloe had discovered them in a corner of [the bare drawing - room]1882-the bare drawing - room , [I]45-chloe had missed the 11.32 . [I]45-chloe went up by the 12.40 , however , and in [the train]1883-the train [I]45-chloe wondered to [myself]45-chloe how it was that [Chloe]45-chloe , who in [the Bandbox had kept all in so neat an array]1884-the bandbox had kept all in so neat an array , was now growing more untidy than [I]45-chloe in [my]45-chloe most reckless moods had ever been . It was a problem , and [I]45-chloe bent [myself]45-chloe to it as [the train]1883-the train whirled [me]45-chloe through green pastures outlined with elm - trees and hawthorn hedges , then through [villas]1886-villas , red and self - consciously trim , with [their]1886-villas neat gardens , geranium - flushed , calceolaria - gilded — neat as a prize map at [a first - class high - school]1887-a first - class high - school . The problem did not resolve itself . It was not till [the train]1883-the train was rushing through a wilderness of [yellow brick houses]1889-yellow brick houses , all alike , all soot - begrimed , all standing , with [their]1886-villas bits of [blackened garden]1890-blackened garden , [their]1886-villas stunted flowers , [their]1886-villas carefully trained snippets of creeper , for lives full of the courageous struggle of [man]1891-man 's innate love of beauty against the iron of environment , the crippling of the accident of birth , the handicap of hereditary submission to the undeserved darkening of life , that [I]45-chloe began to see the answer to [my]45-chloe question . In [[our]1892-we first home]1893-our first home — [the Bandbox]179-the bandbox , [the little nest that had held [us]1892-we at [our]1892-we first mating]1895-the little nest that had held us at our first mating — [Chloe]45-chloe had struggled to reproduce , and had reproduced , on a microscopic scale , and with the aid of [a woman servant more or less tractable]1896-a woman servant more or less tractable , the habits and methods learned in [[[her]45-chloe mother]1645-her mother 's house in [Bedford]15-bedford]1898-her mother 's house in bedford . There were rules , and [she]45-chloe followed them . [I]45-chloe for [my]45-chloe part had met the new rules as part of a new and delightful comedy , wherein [[my]45-chloe wife]162-my wife was [heroine]1900-heroine . At the same time [I]45-chloe had felt no urgent need for altering the habits of years spent in [chambers]1901-chambers , at the mercy of [an uncomplaining and systematically dishonest laundress]1902-an uncomplaining and systematically dishonest laundress . But when [the Bandbox]6-the bandbox — [I]45-chloe paid it the tribute of a perfunctory sigh , even in [[my]45-chloe railway - carriage solitude]1903-my railway - carriage solitude — when the dear Bandbox was left behind , and [we]1892-we entered [the Red House]187-the red house , [we]1892-we entered , too , on a new life — a primitive existence where law was not . The rules [Chloe]45-chloe had learned in [Bedford]15-bedford as to the duties of [servants]1905-servants and the routine of domestic life were now inapplicable , since [we]1892-we had [no servant]279-no servant , and consequently no recognized routine . [We]1892-we were in the position of folk cast upon [a desert island]1907-a desert island ( [I]45-chloe mean [an uninhabited one]1908-an uninhabited one , but the phraseology , as the instinct , of boyhood survives ) . And here [we]1892-we had suddenly changed parts . The chart of custom by which [Chloe]45-chloe had steered in [Bandbox]6-the bandbox days had been reft from [her]45-chloe . [She]45-chloe had nothing left but delightful , genuine impulses towards beauty — the arrangement of flowers , the fixing of shelves , and the deep , eternal instinct to satisfy the cravings of hunger in [herself]45-chloe and [hers]45-chloe — [me]45-chloe . [I]45-chloe , on the other hand , being face to face with a new problem , met it , man fashion , with a new solution . [I]45-chloe perceived that order alone could make [our]1892-we life in [the Red House]187-the red house possible . As [the train]1883-the train steamed over [the bridge]1911-the bridge one practical conclusion came as the result of [my]45-chloe meditations . [Chloe]45-chloe must have [a servant]380-a servant . [I]45-chloe saw [several editors]1913-several editors , received a commission to write a series of articles on foreign politics , and a short story of strong domestic interest . Then [I]45-chloe stood at the corner by [the Mansion House]1914-the mansion house in a meditation so deep as to provoke the amused and contemptuous scrutiny of [[my]45-chloe fellows]1915-my fellows , and at last , just as [a small boy]1916-a small boy was murmuring at [my]45-chloe elbow , “[45-chloe] Makin ' up [your]476-i mind whether [you]476-i 'll be [prime - minister]477-prime - minister or not ? Well , take [your]476-i time , [sir]370-sir ; it 's worth thinkin ' over , ” [I]476-i hailed [a ' bus]1917-a ' bus and was borne away by it . [I]476-i went straight to [[Mrs. May]63-mrs. may 's registry - office in [Tottenham Court Road]17-tottenham court road]1918-mrs. may 's registry - office in tottenham court road . [The ladies who attended to [my]476-i needs]1919-the ladies who attended to my needs seemed to [me]476-i to have the most perfect manners in [the world]267-the world . So well did [they]1919-the ladies who attended to my needs act for [me]476-i that in half an hour [I]476-i had engaged [an amiable general servant , who was to come on the next Monday “[476-i] as ever was]1921-an amiable general servant , who was to come on the next monday “ as ever was . ” “[476-i] Now look here , ” [I]479-you said to [her]479-you , “[479-you] [you]479-you must n't expect [[our]480-we house]481-our house to be like [any one else]407-any one else 's . [We]480-we 're not in the least like [any one else]407-any one else . [We]480-we live in a very large house”—her plump face fell—“but[485-your mistress] [we]480-we only use [a few rooms]484-a few rooms . [[Your]479-you mistress]485-your mistress will help [you]479-you a bit , and [you]479-you can go out one evening a week and every Sunday , and [you]479-you can have [[your]479-you friends]486-your friends to see [you]479-you any evening”—her face brightened—“but[487-no young men] [no young men]487-no young men , unless [they]487-no young men come by twos — see ? [[My]0-i wife]162-my wife and [I]0-i will both help [you]479-you , and if [you]479-you help [us]480-we [we]480-we shall all be perfectly jolly . What do [you]479-you think ? Would [you]479-you like to try ? ” [I]479-you could see the smile [Mrs. May]63-mrs. may was trying to conceal , and [I]479-you felt a tremor of doubt . Perhaps , after all , it did not do to treat [servants]1905-servants as though [they]1905-servants were of the same flesh and blood as [one]1622-one 's self . [The girl]180-the girl hesitated , looked doubtfully at [me]479-you , [I]479-you smiled at [her]180-the girl in [my]479-you best manner , and [she]180-the girl smiled back heartily , and as it seemed to [me]479-you without mental reservations . “[479-you] Well , [sir]370-sir , ” [she]180-the girl said , “[479-you] [we]480-we can but try . ” So that was settled . [I]479-you felt the warm point of triumph which punctuates the career of [the born organizer]1925-the born organizer . “[479-you] Monday , then , ” said [I]479-you ; “[479-you] and send [your]479-you box by [Carter Paterson]64-carter paterson . ” And with that [I]64-carter paterson left well alone , and went back to [Cannon Street]18-cannon street via [the Twopenny Tube]19-the twopenny tube . [I]64-carter paterson had to wait half an hour for [a train]1926-a train . On [the platform]1927-the platform was [the usual dingy , mixed crowd of clerks]1928-the usual dingy , mixed crowd of clerks , [type - writing girls]1929-type - writing girls , [art students]1930-art students , and [City men]1931-city men , and among [them]1928-the usual dingy , mixed crowd of clerks , [her]180-the girl red hair shining at [me]64-carter paterson down the length of [the gloomy platform]1932-the gloomy platform , [a woman]1933-a woman 's figure that [I]64-carter paterson knew . [Her]180-the girl dainty dress of muslin , sown with little bunches of violets , [her]180-the girl charming hat , [her]180-the girl perfect gloves and shoes — these alone might not have thrust [her]180-the girl identity on [me]64-carter paterson . Thank Heaven , [more than one Englishwoman]1934-more than one englishwoman wears pretty muslin gowns and picture - hats , and has gloves and shoes that fit [her]180-the girl . It was the set of [her]180-the girl shoulders , the poise of [her]180-the girl head , the modest , graceful self - possession of [her]180-the girl attitude that made [me]64-carter paterson bold to step behind [her]180-the girl , and , without even a sight of [her]180-the girl face , to murmur over [her]180-the girl shoulder and into the prettiest ear — almost — in [the world]267-the world , “[64-carter paterson] [Yolande]52-yolande ! ” [She]180-the girl turned in a flash , and [her]180-the girl face came to [me]64-carter paterson in that dull place like a gleam of sunlight in a cloudy day . “[64-carter paterson] How unexpected [you]490-you are , ” [I]490-you said , “[490-you] and how very , very like the most beautiful kind of French fashion - plate . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i was going down to see [Chloe]45-chloe — and [you]52-yolande . [Yolande]52-yolande stayed with [us]1948-we three days . The rainbow delights of [[our]1948-we new house]1949-our new house seemed newly dyed when [we]1948-we displayed them to [her]52-yolande appreciative eyes . And [I]0-i felt a new impulse to work , now that [Chloe]45-chloe had some one to bear [her]45-chloe company as [she]45-chloe gathered flowers , rearranged furniture , or struggled , face all aglow , against the fiendish arts of the [kitchen range]1950-kitchen range . [I]0-i wrote half [my]0-i “[0-i] story of strong domestic interest , ” and then stuck fast . There was a scene where [the hero]1951-the hero , on the point of marriage with [a respectable and admired heiress]1952-a respectable and admired heiress , [the friend of childhood]1953-the friend of childhood 's hour , sees , as [he]1951-the hero walks up [the church]1954-the church to [his]1951-the hero bridal , the face of [[his]1951-the hero old love , whom [he]1951-the hero had thought dead]1955-his old love , whom he had thought dead . This scene wanted something besides smartness . It wanted fire , passion , delicacy of handling , strength of grasp . And these qualities , strange to say , eluded [me]0-i . [I]0-i told [my]0-i woes , and received from [Chloe]45-chloe and [Yolande]52-yolande sympathy , but no aid . On that third moonlight evening , when [we]1956-we sat out on the grass , round the sun - dial , and [Yolande]52-yolande sang Spanish and Pyrenean songs to the tinkle of [Chloe]45-chloe 's guitar , [I]0-i almost seemed to surprise in [myself]0-i the force to grapple with that scene and get the better of it ; but when [they]1957-they had gone to bed and [I]0-i sat face to face with [[my]0-i type - writer]1818-my type - writer , the force shrivelled to a very agony of conscious incompetence . [I]0-i wrote three abject sentences , and went to bed hopeless . [I]45-chloe had left it at page thirty - one ; it stood now at page fifty - nine . The story was finished . [I]45-chloe read the pages rapidly . The story was good , very good . All the fire and passion and force [I]45-chloe had longed for and had known to be necessary were here . The story began tamely , and ended in vivid and triumphant drama . “[45-chloe] [Chloe]45-chloe ! ” [I]45-chloe called . Then [she]45-chloe blinked at [me]45-chloe with long lashes , and laughed . [I]45-chloe laughed too . “[45-chloe] The ghost be it ! ” [I]45-chloe said , but [I]45-chloe read in [her]45-chloe laughing eyes the word that sprang to [my]45-chloe own lips—“Yolande[45-chloe] ! ” OF course [we]1965-we have [our]1965-we own little stereotyped code of honor and morality , laid by on the shelf , ready for use , and in it [we]1965-we read vaguely that one may not put one 's name to another 's work , or make money by another 's success . The furniture looked very dirty . “[0-i] Not , [I]0-i fear , the most desirable of [tenants]556-tenants , ” [I]0-i murmured , as [we]528-we delicately withdrew . “[0-i] The furniture looks as if it had come out of the dustbin , and so does [the lady]459-the lady . ” “[459-the lady] Oh , do n't be so harsh , ” said [[my]459-the lady wife]162-my wife ; “[459-the lady] remember what [our]528-we furniture looked like — all dusty and forlorn and friendless — when it sat outside the Bandbox waiting for [the vans]558-the vans . [You]173-my dear might just clean the front doorstep — it 's done with hearth - stone , just like the kitchen hearth . It is enough to discourage [any girl]574-any girl to come to [a house]178-a house wrapped in a mantle of decay , with green mould on the doorstep . Then afterwards [we]528-we 'll do [the kitchen]236-the kitchen together . ” It was with but half a heart that [I]577-i collected pail , hearth - stone , and [house]1822-house - flannel . [I]577-i had to take a scrubbing - brush to the green mould , and [I]577-i wondered why the favorite implement gave [me]577-i so little joy as [I]577-i wielded it . The sudden arrival of [[the new maid]1986-the new maid 's box]1987-the new maid 's box , by [Carter Paterson]64-carter paterson , enlightened [me]577-i . [I]577-i found [myself]577-i now working with vigor and enthusiasm . Since [she]572-that girl really was coming ! [I]577-i knew then that [I]577-i had never believed [she]572-that girl would come , and it had seemed futile to spread milk - white over the doorstep , just for [Chloe]45-chloe and [me]577-i , whose eyes its blotted gray and moss green had always delighted . Now [I]577-i finished the doorstep con amore , and hastened to [the kitchen]236-the kitchen where [Chloe]45-chloe and a hammer were busy together . [I]577-i scrubbed the dressers and the table and the deal shelf that pulls out under the window . [Chloe]45-chloe is always wise enough to feed energy with praise — a diet too often grudged it . “[577-i] [You]577-i do scrub beautifully , ” [she]45-chloe said . “[577-i] [I]0-i believe [you]577-i think the brush is nobler than the pen . ” “[577-i] [You]577-i see [I]0-i am [an able ‘ performer on the instrument]578-an able ‘ performer on the instrument , ’ as [Jane Austen]72-jane austen would say . ” “[72-jane austen] [Dear Jane]73-jane , ” said [Chloe]45-chloe . “[73-jane] There — there 's glory for [you]577-i ! ” [She]45-chloe had nailed up a deep flounce of green and red chintz along the chimney - piece , and another above the windows . A cushion to match nestled in the shabby Windsor arm - chair [we]580-we had recently picked up for two and threepence in [a back street in [Deptford]22-deptford]1989-a back street in deptford . “[73-jane] Is n't it pretty ? Is n't it cosey , and old - fashioned , and farm - housy ? If this does n't make [her]579-her stay , nothing will ! [I]0-i 'll get the hearth - rug out of [[our]580-we bedroom]395-our bedroom . [You]577-i wo n't mind , will [you]577-i ? And do put [your]577-i instrument away — there 's no more scrubbing , and [she]579-her 'll be here directly . Do [you]577-i think [we]580-we could bear to let [her]579-her have two of the brass candlesticks out of [the white parlor]257-the white parlor for this mantel - piece ? ” “[577-i] No , ” [I]577-i said , firmly ; “[577-i] there are limits . But put up the cake - tins — [I]0-i polished them the other day . ” The cake - tins were a shining crown to the splendor of the chintz flounce . [Our]580-we crockery , well spread out upon the two large dressers , made a brave show . [Our]580-we bedroom hearth - rug , also woven of reds and greens , showed up the beauty of the chintz flounce , which in its turn , by its neat newness , added lustre and importance to the hearth - rug . It was indeed a beautiful picture — a poem , even , set to music by the singing of the new kitchen kettle , and [I]0-i did not grudge the sacrifice of the parlor table - cloth to the completion of that radiant harmony . [We]580-we had [our]580-we lunch in a very great hurry , so as to get the plates washed up before [[our]580-we new servant]1990-our new servant came . By two o'clock all was ready . Ever since the joyous day when in [my]0-i well - ironed frock - coat [I]0-i had gone forth and engaged [a servant]380-a servant , [Chloe]45-chloe had ventured , day by day , on more and more daring preparations for [the maid]1992-the maid 's arrival , and [Chloe]45-chloe had dragged [me]0-i with [her]45-chloe . [We]580-we had cleaned [the white parlor]257-the white parlor — when [we]580-we had [a servant]380-a servant [we]580-we could afford to sit in [a parlor]1995-a parlor . [We]580-we had laid down a rug or two on the red - and - white marble of [the hall]1783-the hall , and hung two or three old prints on the dull brown of [its]1783-the hall walls . [We]580-we sat out some oak chairs and the old elm kneading - trough in it by way of furniture . [We]580-we had put up dimity curtains in [[the new maid]1986-the new maid 's bedroom]1998-the new maid 's bedroom : [Chloe]45-chloe insisted on these , not because [she]45-chloe admired the material , but because “[0-i] dimity ” is such a nice word — [the born sister of lavender]1999-the born sister of lavender , and tall presses , and well - scrubbed boards , and patch - work quilts . [We]580-we had a patch - work quilt — the gift of [a gaunt great - aunt of [mine]2001-mine]2000-a gaunt great - aunt of mine — and [we]580-we sacrificed it to the fitness of things , and let [it]2002-it live with the dimity curtains . [Chloe]45-chloe adorned the dimity - covered dressing ing - table with a smart , new pin - cushion with blue bows , and set a blue jug of pink roses on the broad window - sill . [[[Our]580-we servant]2003-our servant 's bedroom]2004-our servant 's bedroom was as pretty as paint . [I]588-you said so , and [Chloe]45-chloe said : “[588-you] Nonsense ! it 's only conventionally correct . [No one]269-no one could live with [us]589-we a month and not see how silly [we]589-we are . It 's better not to try to break things to [people]593-people . Let [her]590-her know the worst at once . [Chloe]45-chloe put [her]45-chloe hand to [her]45-chloe heart . “[0-i] If [I]0-i faint , do n't be surprised . But [you]0-i must pretend to be ! [Chloe]45-chloe and [I]0-i had simplified [our]600-we lives , as [people]593-people always do when [their]593-people own hands supply [their]593-people wants . [Mary]75-mary accepted [Chloe]45-chloe 's assistance for two days , and then gently but firmly declined further help . “ Why , ”[75-mary] [she]75-mary said , “ [I]75-mary could do the work here with one hand behind [me]75-mary ! [The house]1610-the house was always neat and clean , and yet there was time for everything . [I]0-i wrote now , sometimes [we]600-we went to [town]168-town when [we]600-we wanted to go , orders grew , and prosperity seemed , like the rainbow , to be waiting for [us]600-we at the end of [the next field]605-the next field . It was a happy breathing - space . [Yolande]52-yolande wrote , fully endorsing [Chloe]45-chloe 's view , and insisting that the ghost would certainly not have been silly enough to write half a story unless [it]606-it had wanted to see it in print , and recommending [us]600-we to leave the galleys conveniently lying about in [the more haunted - looking parts of [the Red House]187-the red house]607-the more haunted - looking parts of the red house , so that the ghost might , if it pleased , correct [its]606-it own proofs . So [we]600-we sent off the story , and [the editor]167-the editor wrote to [me]0-i . Outside the red wall of [[our]618-our garden]1847-our garden is a strip of ground bounded by a hawthorn hedge , and at the end of this stand [the two cottages]620-the two cottages . [We]618-our passed along [the winding shrubbery - walk]621-the winding shrubbery - walk — by reason of [its]621-the winding shrubbery - walk darkness the only path of [[our]618-our garden]1847-our garden whereon the weeds were not breast - high — and so , pushing through the tall - standing weeds , dock and nettle , sow - thistle and cow - parsley , of [the cottage garden]535-the cottage garden , to the square of ground that stands between [[our]618-our two cottages]624-our two cottages and [the road]625-the road . Here were no juicy , green , upstanding weeds , graceful in their arrogant victory over flowers and fruits . The green weeds were trampled down to a damp , yellow , sodden mass , sordid and evilsmelling . Old meat - cans , sardine - tins , broken boots , decayed brooms , and battered saucepans were strewn around , “ like flowers at a festival . ”[0-i] Dirty rags festooned the faded blue of the railings ; the family linen , wetted but not washed , hung on the elder - bushes , whose white blossoms drooped degraded under the foul burden . A very dirty blanket hung out of the bedroom window , and on the doorstep , among dust and flue , bones , crusts , and the miscellaneous sweepings of a filthy floor , [three indescribably unengaging children , with dirty noses]626-three indescribably unengaging children , with dirty noses , were playing moodily and without smiles . [Their]626-three indescribably unengaging children , with dirty noses playthings were a blade - bone of mutton , two muddy clothes - pegs , and a dead mouse . [Chloe]45-chloe is absurdly fond of [children]627-children , but — or , perhaps , therefore — [she]45-chloe turned away with a shudder . [We]618-our went [home]244-home boiling with indignation , but in the crucible of [our]618-our thought [our]618-our rage , as it cooled , left as precipitate the unmistakable consciousness of [our]618-our own incompetence . True , as [Chloe]45-chloe said , it was [she]45-chloe who had accepted [a tenant so manifestly undesirable — lured by a bait of fourteen shillings a month]629-a tenant so manifestly undesirable — lured by a bait of fourteen shillings a month . [She]45-chloe had done it , but [I]0-i had stood by and let it be done . Now , however , [I]0-i must act . [I]0-i would act . Was it , [I]0-i wonder , an inexcusable cowardice or a wise discretion which led [me]0-i to refrain from giving [Mr. Prosser]71-prosser notice in a personal interview ? [I]0-i wrote to [him]71-prosser , and bade [him]71-prosser leave [[my]0-i cottage]630-my cottage at the end of the week . But at the end of the week [he]71-prosser was still [there]1621-there , and on the Monday evening , as [Chloe]45-chloe and [I]0-i wandered in [the green forest of weeds]632-the green forest of weeds and flowers that was [[our]633-our garden]1847-our garden , the spell of its silence was broken for [us]633-our by the sound of [Mr. Prosser]71-prosser 's voice , uplifted in one of the less agreeable comic songs of the year before the year before last . [I]0-i went down at once to give [him]71-prosser , personally , that notice to quit which [I]0-i found [him]71-prosser in no fit state to receive . Another call , in the morning , found [[my]0-i tenant]635-my tenant conscious , indeed , but little amenable . “ [I]71-prosser gave [you]71-prosser written notice to quit last week , ”[71-prosser] said [I.]0-i “ How is it [you]71-prosser 've not gone ? ”[0-i] [Mr. Prosser]71-prosser , unshaved , without tie , collar , or boots , settled [his]71-prosser head between [his]71-prosser shoulders , and said [he]71-prosser did n't know anything about no notice . “ Well , anyhow , ”[0-i] said [I]0-i , “ [you]71-prosser 've got to clear out now . [I]71-prosser want [the cottage]534-the cottage . ”[71-prosser] “ Right [you]0-i are , [sir]370-sir , ”[71-prosser] said [he]71-prosser , “ but there must be proper notice give an ' took . ”[0-i] “ [I]0-i give [you]71-prosser notice now , ”[0-i] said [I]0-i , “ and , while [I]635-my tenant am [here]231-here , suppose [you]71-prosser hand over the rent . ”[635-my tenant] Then [[my]0-i tenant]635-my tenant drew [himself]635-my tenant up and uttered these memorable words : “ [I]0-i 'm [a yearly tenant]2053-a yearly tenant , [I]0-i am , and [I]0-i pays on quarter - day , and six months ' notice is what [I]0-i 'm entitled to . ‘ Nine pun two a year , ’ [[your]0-i missus]2054-your missus said . ”[0-i] “ Very well . [I]45-chloe shall consult [[my]45-chloe solicitor]2055-my solicitor , ”[45-chloe] [I]0-i said , and turned away helpless . [I]0-i did n't know — how should [I]0-i , though [I]0-i had kicked [my]0-i heels , briefless , in [the Inner Temple]637-the inner temple for at least two years — whether [he]635-my tenant was entitled to that or anything else . [I]0-i wrote to [[my]0-i solicitor]2055-my solicitor . [I]0-i had never had [a solicitor]639-a solicitor before , but [I]0-i acquired one at once — [an old chum]640-an old chum . [He]2055-my solicitor wrote [me]0-i three pages of advice , in which a writ of ejectment loomed large . But [his]2055-my solicitor private opinion , as [I]0-i read it between the lines , seemed to be that [I]0-i had got [myself]0-i into a tight place by [my]0-i own folly , and had better trust to time to get [me]0-i out of [it]641-it . [[Our]642-our garden]1847-our garden 's peace was broken . [We]642-our never knew now when the hoarse , raucous voice of [[our]642-our tenant]1980-our tenant might desecrate the moonlit stillness with coarse echoes of transpontine musichalls . The knowledge of [Mr. Prosser]71-prosser 's nearness seemed to smirch the clean sweetness of life . The very jasmine stars seemed less white for the presence of [[our]642-our tenant]1980-our tenant 's sordid ménage on the other side of [our]642-our red wall . And [Mary]75-mary , day by day , tormented [us]642-our with fresh tales of what was being said in [the village of [[our]642-our tenant]1980-our tenant 's antecedents and character , and , by implication , of [ours]642-our]646-the village of our tenant 's antecedents and character , and , by implication , of ours . And all the time [my]0-i inability to set steadfastly to work was fretting at [my]0-i self - control . It is like a mouse gnawing at the cord of life — the longing to work , and the inability to conquer the thousand tiny obstacles that fate erects — fate , backed by one 's own folly in having “ bitten off a larger chunk than one can chew”;—I[651-the lover] still think that a most excellent phrase , and not vulgar , only homely , going straight to the mark as the homely expression of a great truth may be permitted to do . [Chloe]45-chloe was worried also — [[her]45-chloe editors]648-her editors were clamoring for the illustrations which [she]45-chloe was now incapable of working at . And [Mr. Prosser]71-prosser was a live blister , and , like a blister , [he]71-prosser hurt more and more the longer [we]642-our had to bear with [him]71-prosser . [I]0-i was sitting in [[our]642-our little work - room]649-our little work - room one morning , pen in hand , hardly able to meet with a confident eye the white paper that , as [I]0-i stared at it , seemed to stare at [me]0-i in return — to stare rudely , contemptuously , in the confident superiority of its fulfilment of its destiny , as opposed to [my]0-i manifest inability to fulfil [mine]0-i . It was waiting to be written on , and [no one]269-no one could ask more of it . And [I]0-i was waiting to write on it ; and a good deal more than mere waiting was obviously demanded of [me]0-i by [our]642-our financial circumstances and [my]0-i own self - respect . The six stories—“in the style of the ghost”—I[0-i] longed to get them written with a longing more desperate than the longing of [the lover]651-the lover for [[his]651-the lover mistress]652-his mistress , [the mother for [her]653-the mother for her child child]653-the mother for her child . Though more desperate , it had not , however , the force of these natural desires , because it was not a desire for the thing in itself — not a desire to achieve , to attain — but depended for its vitality on a secondary motive . [I]0-i longed to write the stories because [I]0-i wanted the money [they]654-they would bring to [me]0-i . The longing was keen enough to be painful , not strong enough to get itself satisfied . So [I]0-i sat idle , and drew fancy portraits of [Chloe]45-chloe on the blotting - paper . [I]0-i turned it over hastily as [I]0-i heard [her]45-chloe footstep on the [kitchen]1731-kitchen floor , and [I]0-i was bending over a virgin quarto page rimmed with unsoiled pink when [she]45-chloe came in . [I]0-i drew [my]0-i breath in sharply . [Her]45-chloe face , [her]45-chloe eyes , [her]45-chloe whole bearing announced disaster unspeakable . “ What is it ? ”[45-chloe] [I]0-i cried , and [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i must have turned pale . “ [Len]47-len , do [you]47-len love [me]0-i ? ”[0-i] [she]45-chloe asked , clasping [her]45-chloe hands with a charming dramatic movement . “ Better than [my]0-i life , of course , ”[0-i] [I]0-i said , hurriedly , “ but [I]45-chloe 'm just starting on this story , and if it 's some domestic detail — ”[45-chloe] “ No , it ca n't wait , ”[45-chloe] said [she]45-chloe , sitting down on the edge of the table , “ and it 's not a variation on the domestic theme .
